title: Pain Relief Study
question_text:
A doctor wishes to investigate pain relief medications aspirin and acetaminophen. The doctor has $600\text{ volunteers}$ for this study.
The doctor randomly selects $200$ of these volunteer subjects receive aspirin, $200$ to receive acetaminophen and the remaining $200$ to receive a placebo pill.
Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The sample size should be larger for an experiment such as this one.
A placebo, in this case, is not necessary.
A matched pairs design should have been used in this case instead of the process described.
The doctor should have let the subjects choose which group they want to be in so that the subjects feel more comfortable.
This experiment should be conducted in a double-blind manner.

solution:
Three major principles of good experimental design are control, randomize, and replicate.

Ideally, this experiment should be conducted in a double-blind manner, where the subjects and the experiment administrator are all unaware of who receives which treatment.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the condition of replication is met as 200 subjects
are involved in each treatment group.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; a placebo is necessary to act as a control group. This helps serve as a baseline to compare how effective these drugs are compared to nothing.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a matched pairs experiment would not work in this context as the subjects cannot reasonably perform two treatments.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; the subjects should be randomly placed in groups to reduce bias.
